sect1.title: Kernel: Page-Cache Limit
sect1.remark: The presentation of Problem/Solution is on one hand quite useful, on the other it is very inconsistent with the rest of this chapter. - sknorr, 2016-02-12

listitem.para: The kernel swaps out rarely accessed memory pages to use freed memory pages as cache to speed up file system operations, for example during backup operations.

&netweaver; and &hana; use large amounts of memory for accelerated access to business data. Parts of this memory are rarely accessed. When a user request needs to access paged-out memory, the response time is poor. It is even worse when an SAP application running on Java incurs a Java garbage collection: The system starts heavy page-in (disc I/O) activity and has a poor response time for an extended period of time.

&sles4sap; includes a kernel tuning option that allows the system administrator to limit the amount of page cache that the kernel uses when there is competition between application memory and page-cache. This option tells the kernel that when the page cache is filled to the configured limit, application memory is more important and should thus not be paged out. No pages will be paged out if the memory footprint of the workload plus the configured page-cache limit do not exceed the amount of physical RAM in the system.
These kernel options are available for configuration:
vm.pagecache_limit_mb (/proc/sys/vm/pagecache_limit_mb)
vm.pagecache_limit_ignore_dirty (/proc/sys/vm/pagecache_limit_ignore_dirty)

tip.title: Use tuned to Configure These Parameters
tip.para: The parameters vm.pagecache_limit_imb and vm.pagecache_limit_ignore_dirty are also configured by the tuned profiles delivered with the package sapconf.

sect1.para: Using tuned-adm, you can automatically tune a system for &netweaver; and &hana;/&b1; applications. To do so, tuned-adm relies on the system tuning service tuned.

If you used the &sapwiz; to install an SAP application, tuned is usually already active and configured with the profile for the application you installed. Otherwise, make sure that the packages tuned and sapconf are installed on your system.

sect1.title: Configuring &susefirewall;
sect1.para: By default, the installation workflow of &sles4sap; enables &susefirewall;. The firewall needs to be manually configured to allow network access for the following:

listitem.para: SAP application
Database (see the documentation of your database vendor; for &hana;, see )

sect1.para: Additionally, open the ports 1128 (TCP) and 1129 (UDP).
SAP applications require many open ports and port ranges in the firewall. The exact numbers depend on the selected instance. For more information, see the documentation provided to you by SAP.

sect1.title: Configuring HANA-Firewall
sect1.para: To simplify setting up a firewall for &hana;, install the package HANA-Firewall. Whereas standard &susefirewall; allows only three zones (internal, DMZ, and external), HANA-Firewall enables you to configure more zones to accommodate all running &hana; instances.
HANA-Firewall works by adding rule sets to your existing &susefirewall; configuration.
HANA-Firewall consists of the following parts:

formalpara.title: &yast; Module SAP HANA Firewall
formalpara.para: Allows configuring, applying, and reverting firewall rules for &hana; from a graphical user interface.

formalpara.title: Command-Line Utility hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Allows applying and reverting the configured firewall rules for &hana;.

listitem.para: If you prefer, you can configure the rule sets using the configuration file at /etc/sysconfig/hana-firewall instead of using &yast;.

formalpara.title: Service hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Ensures that configured firewall rules for &hana; are kept.

sect1.title: Cleaning Up an Instance Before Using It as a Master Image
sect1.para: Using a system like &kiwi;, it is possible to use an image of an already-configured master instance on multiple systems. However, normally such an image would contain certain configuration data that should not be copied along with the rest of the system.
To avoid needing to clean up manually, use the script clone-master-clean-up (available from the package of the same name). It deletes the following data automatically:

listitem.para: Swap device (zero-wiped, then re-enabled)
SUSE registration information and repositories from SUSE
User and host SSH keys
Shell history, mails, cron jobs, temporary files, log files, random seeds
The generated HANA-Firewall script (but not the configuration itself)
Network configuration

sect1.para: Additionally, sudo settings are reset and you can choose to set up a new &rootuser; password. This script also ensures that, if the first-boot section of the installation workflow was used for the original installation, it is run again on the next boot.

sect1.title: Creating Images with &kiwi;
sect1.para: &sles4sap; now supports creating &kiwi; images using the template from the package kiwi-template-sap. However, there are a few restrictions to the current implementation:

listitem.para: Only building VMX disk images is supported. Building other image types is not supported.
You must provide an ISO image of &sles4sap; at /tmp/SLES4SAP.iso, as the &obs; does not contain all necessary packages.

sect1.para: To enable running graphical installations using &sapina;, the default settings of the image contain an IceWM desktop and start the service sapvnc which allows you to connect to the machine via VNC.
To build a basic image, use the following two commands:
